bibl.title: Letter from L. O. Howard to Jefferson Randolph Kean, May 7, 1924

div1.p: Howard informs Kean of Baekeland's letter to the New York Times Editor and encloses copies of correspondence relating to that letter. [Courtesy of The Albert and Shirley Small Special Collections Library, University of Virginia Library]

div1.head: Letter from L. O. Howard to Jefferson Randolph Kean, May 7, 1924
div1.opener:
UNITED STATES DEPARTMENT OF AGRICULTURE
BUREAU OF ENTOMOLOGY
WASHINGTON, D. C.
May 7, 1924.
Col. J. R. Kean, U.S. Army,
Army Base,
Boston 9, Mass.
My dear Colonel Kean:
div1.p:
Yours of the 6th of May has just come. If you will refer once
more to my letter of May 1st (if you have saved it) you will be interested
to know that a letter came to me this morning from Doctor Baekeland en-
closing a manuscript letter which he wished to send to the New York Times.
I am enclosing a copyof his letter,one of his proposed letter to the
New York Times and one of my reply to him.

I am very glad that you are coming to Washington to live. I
should like to talk to you about those old times and other things. It
seems strange to refer to 1900 and 1901 as “old times,” but I suppose
that is the way most people look at it.
div1.closer:
Sincerely yours, L. O. Howard Chief of Bureau.
